meet Labour’s established tests and Tory Brexiteers in open opposition – bringing the question of what happens if the prime minister’s deal fails into sharp focus.Mr Corbyn would prefer a new election over a referendum, bringing with it the chance of broader power, but leader’s office insiders are said to be increasingly doubtful about the chances of Tory MPs allowing one to happen before 2022.Brexit campaigner Banks claims he has joined the ConservativesNo-deal Brexit could disrupt delivery of foreign sperm to BritainI’ve written my own Brexit impact paper. It says ‘forget it’Drug companies told to stockpile extra medicines for no-deal BrexitCorbyn will be prime minister if our party backs another referendumNationalism makes you weak, poor and morally insecure, EU warnsShadow cabinet members are going through the same thought process, with several now moving towards the idea that another referendum is likely.One shadow cabinet source said: “In the end when the government can’t decide, and when parliament can’t decide, it feels like it might be the only way out.”Pressure to start explicitly pushing for a new vote has been steadily increasing from unions, the Momentum activist group and significant parts of the parliamentary party.The Independent reported earlier this week that the Co-operative Party – Labour’s sister organisation – which counts three shadow cabinet ministers and eight other frontbenchers among its ranks, is now planning to hold a vote on whether to back a new referendum at its conference in October.But any movement towards a new vote also carries political danger, with some Labour MPs in Brexit voting areas likely to be unhappy with the idea.Shadow international trade secretary Barry Gardiner claimed earlier this week that there could be “civil disobedience” in the case of a new referendum.Mr Gardiner said Remain and Leave campaigners told voters at the 2016 referendum that their decision “will determine the future of our country for the next 40 or 50 years”.He added: “If you then say to people ‘We did give you a vote and actually we, the Remainers, lost the vote, but because you were stupid enough to do what you wanted rather than what we wanted ... we’ll give you another chance to get it right’ – that undermines the whole principle of democracy in this country.”The Independent has launched its title: pets dogs toxic algae lake swim
story: Dogs become ill quite easily says David Grant  (Image:  )A - Although the term algae is used, the cause of the problem is bacterial.Cyanobacteria are often found in lakes and ponds in very hot weather, forming a blue-green scum on the surface.Affected water can look like pea soup. Some of the cyanobacteria can produce toxins that are dangerous to animals.Assume that when the blue-green colour is present, toxins are also in the water.                 Forget dolphins, go to the Algarve to swim with Portugese Water Dogs                Dog news: Labrador becomes dad to NINE adorable ducklings herdingThere are two main dangers, depending on whether the toxin has caused liver damage or affected the central nervous system.Signs of liver failure include vomiting, diarrhoea, lethargy, refusing to eat and jaundice.Nervous system problems include disorientation, collapse and seizures. Dogs are typically very ill and need immediate intensive veterinary treatment to survive.The risk to cats is smaller as they are unlikely to swim but may come into contact with the algae on the banks of an affected lake.David Grant MBE was a vet at the RSPCA Harmsworth Hospital for Animals. Write to him at Express Yourself, 10 Lower Thames Street, London EC3R 6EN. He is unable to enter into inidual correspondence.

story: The group, also known as the Junge Union, campaigns in favour of Brussels on behalf of Germany&rsquos young people and now argues that as many young Britons voted Remain in the 2016 EU referendum the nation should be automatically re-admitted back into bloc in 2035.Though he was unable to explain why the year 2035 was so significant in the group&rsquos plot, youth leader Paul Ziemiak, an ally of Ms Merkel, said Britain&rsquos proposed re-entry back into the EU was to &ldquocorrect the decision of the 51.9 percent that voted Leave.Mr Ziemiak, who called his campaign &lsquoBrit-In&rsquo, said: &ldquoOur goal is a re-entry of Great Britain in 2035.&ldquoIn polls less than a quarter of 18 to 24-year-old British people were in favour of an exit of Great Britain from the EU.                'Its not a JOKE Mr Corbyn' Labour leader AVOIDS Brexit question AGAIN                EU WILL PAY: No-deal Brexit will spark financial DISASTER for BrusselsHe added that because of the low votes for Brexit by Britain&rsquos younger voters, that qualifies as a reason for the entire nation to be re-shackled to Brussels.Around 73 percent of people under 24 voted to remain in the EU during the June 2016 referendum.But just 36 percent of those in that age bracket voted, meaning 36 percent did not bother.The Young Union believes Brexit would have triggered the creation of pro-EU youth groups in the UK.Paul Ziemiak did explain that Britain&rsquos proposed re-entry back into the EU was to &ldquocorrect Brexit (Image: )                Angela Merkel slaps down her OWN minister for attacking Donald Trump                EU news: Italy spends &euro200,000 Brussels grant in migration protestThe Young Union was established in 1947 and their headquarters are in Berlin.The group aims to further the goals of their parent political parties - in their case German Chancellor Angela Merkel&rsquos pro-EU Christian Democratic Union (CDU).The Young Union advocates political reform and says it supports intergenerational equality.Mr Ziemiak, 33, is a Polish-born politician and became chairman of the Young Union in 2012.Britain&rsquos official exit from the EU is now just six months away in March 2019 (Image: )Britain&rsquos official exit from the EU is now just six months away in March 2019.Theresa May&rsquos Government recently announced they are preparing for a no-deal Brexit following gruelling negotiations between Brexit secretary Dominic Raab and EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier.European Commission president Jean-Claude Juncker said in January that he hoped Britain would apply to rejoin the EU at some point.Additional reporting by Monika Pallenberg.

story: Dominic Raab is due to make an announcement regarding the no-deal Brexit arrangements  (Image: )Leaked documents obtained by The Sun reveal that pensioners who have contributed to schemes in Europe could risk losing their access to their pension funds if they are paid into a UK bank account.At the moment, there are Brussels rules that pensions from EU countries must be paid into EU accounts.UK-based firms are allowed to make payments into bank accounts in European Economic area states and the same applies the other way round.However, if access to this is lost, UK-based firms will not be able to make the payments.                UK is ready for 'SMOOTH' Brexit insists Raab amid fears of COLLAPSE                'Don't underestimate Boris' Jeremy Hunt suggests Johnson could be PMLending, deposit services and insurance would also be affected if the Government does not make any changes before the UK leaves the EU and the rules stay the same.Therefore, UK residents would need to open accounts on the continent to collect their pension allowance.When the UK leaves the EU next year, there is even concern that expats could have their UK bank accounts having their payments stopped.The Financial Conduct Authority has announced plans to mitigate the impact for those pensioners with EU-based pensions.Pensioners living in the EU could be affected by the changes on their pensions  (Image:  )Director of regulation at the Association of British Insurers, High Savill, said: &ldquoWe urge the Government to agree a deal as a matter of urgency.&ldquoToday's paper emphasises the risk of insurers not being able to make payments to customers based in the EU after the end of March next year.&ldquoInsurers have of course been making contingency plans for their own operations for many months now, but this contract issue is not one that insurers themselves can fix.The Government is making contingency plans incase there is a no-deal Brexit  (Image: )The document revealing the pension news comes from the contingency plans published by the Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab.Brexit Secretary Domnic Raab has said: &ldquoThe plans are a a sensible, measured,and proportionate approach to minimising the impact of no deal on British firms, citizens, charities and public bodies.The papers also reveal that UK consumers could face increased costs and slower processing times for Euro transactions.The UK is expected to leave the EU in March 2019 amid fears of a no-deal but Mr Raab insists he has time to strike an agreement by the October deadline.

title: wendy house queen buckingham palace windsor castle
story: Princess Elizabeth, the future Queen, right, with sister Princess Margaret outside the Wendy house  (Image: TOPFOTO  RETRONAUT  MEDIADRUMIMAGES )But the Queen&rsquos first house was just 24ft-long, and was presented to her as a sixth birthday present in 1932.This charming Wendy house was given to the future queen on behalf of &ldquothe people of Wales and holds a special place in the heart of the monarch.These newly released pictures, recently discovered in royal archives, show the then Princess Elizabeth posing outside the house with her sister Princess Margaret, who was then nearly two.The life-size doll house, entitled The Little House, was intended as a symbol of the love and fascination of the Welsh people for the beloved young princess.                Meghan Markle and Prince Harry enjoy Scotland break with Charles an...                Prince Charles won't need this when he is KingThe two-thirds size cottage, with 5ft-high rooms, was moved from Wales to the grounds of the Royal Lodge of Windsor, where it remains to this day, tucked away from public view in the south side of the gardens. Over the years, the Queen&rsquos children have also played in the Wendy house and, more recently, her grandchildren. It has a thatched roof, a working doorbell and a sign above the door reading &ldquoY Bwthyn Bach, which means The Little House in Welsh. The whitewashed building is entered by a small hallway with a kitchen to the right, while a staircase gives access to a bedroom and a bathroom, which, when it was first built, was very modern, with hot and cold running water, a heated towel rail and electricity.&nbspIn the kitchen there was a gas cooker, fridge and even a miniature-sized telephone.The young princesses by the little home&rsquos own sundi...right, Elizabeth plays with her dogs at house  (Image: TOPFOTO  RETRONAUT  MEDIADRUMIMAGES  )The house is set in its own garden, with manicured lawns, a path, shrubs and a sundial.But the charming gift did not come without its drama.While the Wendy house was in transit from Wales, a tarpaulin protecting it caught fire, destroying the thatched roof and many of the timbers.Luckily, the Sea Insurance Company had issued a miniature fire policy for &pound750 on the building and &pound500 on the contents.Craftsmen working on the damaged house at Olympia, London, after fire in 1932 (Image: TOPFOTO  RETRONAUT  MEDIADRUMIMAGES)The pictures show craftsmen working to repair the damage, before the house was reconstructed in Windsor Great Park for Elizabeth after it was displayed at London&rsquos Olympia exhibition centre.It holds a special place in the hearts of all the royal children, but Princess Beatrice was especially captivated by it, once calling it &ldquothe most glamorous Wendy house ever.In 2012, she oversaw its complete refurbishment over the course of a year.Speaking at the time, Beatrice said: &ldquoGranny was very clear that for all the fabric she wanted very little designs. It&rsquos such a little house that she wanted little flowers and patterns. It&rsquos beautiful.

story: Travellers have invaded a car park close to the millionaire's playground of Sandbanks (Image: RogerArbonBNPS)They are even more appalled at their local council after officials visited the travellers to supply them with a Portaloo and a skip rather than evict them there and then.It is thought the group took over the car park having been moved on from another site in nearby Bournemouth where they are said to have caused havoc.The group were blamed for a series of fights in the town's pubs and squirting families with super-soaker guns.Pictures taken of the camp show bikes strewn across the ground and seating areas made up of folding chairs in front of several mobile homes.                UK flights: Best airline for free hand luggage                Travellers barred from whole towns: Draconian laws used in crackdownLocals believe their arrival coincides with the popular Bournemouth Air Show even that takes place from August 30.Poole Borough Council have served the group with an eviction notice and that it is currently going through the courts.The process is expected to be concluded by the end of the week, but locals have been quick to voice their fury that more has not been done.Sheena Ogilvy said: I think all the MPs, police and magistrates need to grow some backbone and use the laws and deal with the problems. Call in the army.The local council gave the travellers a Portaloo and skip (Image: Roger Arbon  BNPS)I'm fed up with being a council taxpayer and a UK taxpayer and seeing this happening in so many counties effecting friends and family, it's got out of hand.&nbspAnother resident, who chose to remain anonymous, added: It's getting to the point where residents should start withholding some of their council tax on the grounds that the authorities are not using the funds to keep these criminals away.I'd support the withheld funds being spent on private security as it would seem like the police lack either the funding or willpower to deal with this mob.&nbspLocal businesses say they've also been affected by the illegal encampment.                UK train routes which cost more than flights to EuropeOne woman, who works in a nearby convenience store, said staff had to be on the guard when the travellers in the shop.Bob Reid, chairman of the local residents association, said: This visit from the traveller community is almost becoming an annual event unfortunately and it's the last thing you want in an area like this.Last year they actually left a whole caravan behind, which I believe the local council had to deal with.They also stole a ball from a handball event that was going on, and when a woman tried to get it back, they assaulted her.The car park is within yards of the holiday beaches (Image: Googlemaps)It's not the type of place you might expect to get travellers but sadly they have taken over once again.&nbspMohan Iyengar, a local councillor for Canford Cliffs, said: Unfortunately, as with most councils, we are very used to dealing with issues relating to the traveller community.As soon as we knew they had arrived they were paid a visit by an officer who served them with their notice, but it has to go through the courts.The process usually takes around three or four days so my guess is that they should have been moved on by the end of this week.In the meantime we have to do whatever we can to try and minimise damage to residents and ensure that the clean-up afterwards is as quick as possible.Meanwhile, a local MP has pledged to fight for tougher sanctions on the illegal camps, labelling travellers 'a blight on the community'.Conor Burns, the MP for nearby Bournemouth West, said: This issue has been a running sore throughout the entire time that I have been a Member of Parliament and before.Poole Borough Council has issued an eviction notice (Image: RogerArbonBNPS)There are inadequate enforcement powers to swiftly move on these illegally-set up camps in settled communities, causing profound disturbance to decent people who make their full contribution to society and pay their taxes.&nbspI have consistently urged government to review legislation to give police greater powers to deal with this blight on our community.&nbspA Poole council spokesman added: We are aware that there is an encampment of both of caravans and camper vans on Beach Road Car Park.We will be organising toilets and a skip to avoid contamination of the area.

story: The LBC radio host demanded to know if former Tony Blair spin doctor Alastair Campbell&rsquos dog was a Remainer after it interrupted the live radio interview.Speaking to the radio host, Mr Campbell said: &ldquoThis is not Project Fear now, this is Project Reality where an awful lot of chickens are coming home to roost.&ldquoSurely, as we now seem to have a very significant part of the Conservative Party that is actively fighting for no-deal and all the economic and social damage that is going to do, surely now we are reaching that point where the people have to be given a say on whether this is what they meant by Brexit.It&rsquos a complete mess and what we are seeing today is the possibility that it&rsquos not just a mess but it becomes a total catastrophe for this country. He said: &ldquoSo all these other issues that you regularly and rightly talk about on your programme, whether it is the crisis in prisons, whether it is the growing knife crime in the capital, all of these issues are barely addressed.&ldquoWhether it is the crisis in young people and mental health &ndash these are barely&nbspbeing addressed&nbspbecause we have a Government utterly fixated on trying to do something that deep down - sorry that was my dog - they know it&rsquos going to be damaging to the country.The LBC host burst out laughing and said: &ldquoPerhaps your dog is a&nbspRemainer&nbsptoo?Brexit news: Alastair Campbell pleaded for second Brexit referendum (Image: LBC)Brexit secretary Dominic Raab hit out at Project Fear on Thursday. title: Brexit news update David Davis EU UK Brexit no deal Chequers
story: Speaking on TalkRadio, Mr Davis claimed despite Theresa May's proposal would not fully deliver the Brexit Britons voted for in the June&nbsp2016 referendum, any outcome would still be better than remaining in the Brussels bloc.The former Brexit Secretary, who quit in protest to the Prime Minister's Chequers proposal, argued UK trade will undoubtedly flourish outside the EU.He said: &ldquoThe majority of our trade is going to the rest of the world, we will reinforce those things.&ldquoI think under any circumstance we&rsquore going to be better off outside the union.                British businessman DISMISSES fears of no deal Brexit with KEY point                Brexit news: 'Disruption REGARDLESS' &ndash EU responds to UK no-deal plans&ldquoBut I do still think that the proposal from Chequers, which I argued against very firmly on the day, will not meet the undertakings we got from people.&ldquoAnd that&rsquos the fundamental problem.Brexit Secretary&nbspDominic Raab&nbspinsisted on Thursday that an agreement is within our sights and that about 80 percent of the issues standing in the way of a withdrawal deal had been resolved.Mr Raab gave a speech in London to present a series of 25 technical notices outlining contingency plans for business and industries to prepare for an abrupt exit from the EU.Brexit news: David Davis claims any Brexit outcome will be better than staying in the EU (Image: )He said: We have made clear that if negotiations don't achieve the optimum outcome we will continue to be a responsible European neighbour and partner.&nbspWe have a duty, as a responsible government, to plan for every eventuality. These technical notices, and the ones that will follow, are a sensible, measured, and proportionate approach to minimising the impact of no deal on British firms, citizens, charities and public bodies.British businesses will have to declare all imports from the continent and pay customs duties, also treating EU nations as third countries after a no deal Brexit, according to one of the Brexit papers.The paper warned firms will have to apply the same customs procedures as they do when importing goods from a country outside the EU.It said: This means that for goods entering the UK from the EU an import declaration will be required. Customs checks may be carried out and any customs duties must be paid.Brussels&rsquo chief negotiator Michel Barnier voiced his concerns of an EU &ldquoblame game emerging in British no-deal debates.After meeting with Mr Raab on Tuesday, the Frenchman said: &ldquoTo be very frank with you, I do see this blame game starting against the European Union in the case of no deal.&ldquoBut the European Union is not going to be impressed by that kind of blame game, everyone should understand that.

story: But the Cabinet Office Minister insisted there are powerful and persuasive arguments for keeping the Union intact even without a Brussels deal.He also said the UK Government had shared its technical notes on such scenario with the Scottish and Welsh governments, incorporating feedback on devolved areas.The SNP's Constitutional Relations Secretary Mike Russell has urged the UK ministers to rule out the option.He claimed Scotland faced a no deal Brexit nightmare as the first of a series of papers on the issue were published. Exit talks will &lsquoSLIP&rsquo past OctoberHis administration wants to remain in the EU's single market and customs union and repeatedly complained about having little involvement in the leave process.Edinburgh and London have also been embroiled in a long-running row over the distribution of responsibilities repatriated from Brussels.But Mr Lidington said Brexit discussions with the devolved administrations are constructive and business-like, with Scottish and Welsh ministers given input into the technical notices.He said: I think that the merits of the union of the United Kingdom are still there and are still very powerful and persuasive regardless of the outcome to the European negotiations.A no deal would NOT jeopardise the Union (Image: getty)Mike Russell has argued the documents have only added to uncertainty on Brexit (Image: getty)The UK Government is absolutely determined to get a deal and a deal that works well for all parts of the United Kingdom, but I think if you look at this just in crude business and economic terms I think the value to Scotland of the single market of the United Kingdom, the ability to buy and sell in every part of the United Kingdom, is something that is of huge value to businesses and customers in Scotland.The UK Government argues the advice for businesses, citizens and public bodies will ensure the UK economy keeps running smoothly and Mr Lidington said some were changed as a result of comments from either Scotland or Wales.                German MEP claims Brexit no-deal would be economic 'nightmare'                UK is ready for 'SMOOTH' Brexit insists Raab amid fears of COLLAPSEI accept that there needs to be continuing awareness in Whitehall about the fact that we are operating in a constitution where significant areas of policy delivery are devolved, he added.Departments need to be alive to that in their drafting and their consultation processes.Meanwhile, Mr Russell argued the documents only add to the uncertainty surrounding Brexit.He said: These technical notices reveal the 'no deal' Brexit nightmare facing Scotland and lay bare the risks facing Scottish businesses, the economy and public services.

title: brexit news jeremy hunt brexit vote no deal papers UK government leave EU dominic raab
story: Brexit news: Mr Hunt said the Government would only accept a deal in line with the referendum result (Image: )Jeremy Hunt, who on Wednesday urged the EU to stand &ldquoshoulder to shoulder with the UK in response to the Salisbury Novichok attacks, imploring the bloc to impose fresh sanctions on the Kremlin, is on his first US visit in his new Government post.The Foreign Secretary added MPs would only accept a Brexit deal which was consistent with the &ldquoletter and spirit of the 2016 referendum result to leave the EU.He asserted the Government would only &ldquoever put to Parliament a deal that gave the British people what they voted for.The MP for South West Surrey said: &ldquoI think Parliament will only accept a deal that is consistent with the letter and spirit of the referendum result - the decision by the British people to leave the European Union - and indeed that is the only agreement that Theresa May and her Government, of which I am part, would ever put to Parliament.                Dominic Raab delivers BRILLIANT reply to question Corbyn can't answer                'Don't underestimate Boris' Jeremy Hunt suggests Johnson could be PM&ldquoAnd we are hopeful, cautiously hopeful, rather than wildly hopeful, that we will come to an agreement with the EU because we think it's in their interests as well as ours.&ldquoThat is both the right thing in terms of continuing to keep Britain as a great friend and partner of European nations going forward, but also one that's compatible with the desire of the British people to change our legal relationship with the EU and that's what we're working very hard to achieve.Brexit secretary Dominic Raab said reaching a deal with the EU was the &ldquooverriding priority and &ldquoby far the most likely outcome but &ldquowe must be ready to consider the alternative.Mr Raab also dismissed what he labelled as &ldquowilder claims about the impact of not reaching a deal, including that it could spark a &ldquosandwich famine in the UK.Brexit news: UN Secretary-General Anthonio Guterres meets Jeremy Hunt on Wednesday (Image: )Brexit news: Mr Raab takes part in a question and answer session after delivering a speech in London (Image: )He said: &ldquoLet me assure you that, contrary to one of the wilder claims, you will still be able to enjoy a BLT after Brexit, and there are no plans to deploy the Army to maintain food supplies.Mr Hunt's remarks on a no-deal Brexit came just hours after the Government released the first batch of contingency papers predicting the impact of a no-deal Brexit.The papers outlined guidance for businesses who could face extra red tape at borders and measures to avoid medicine shortages.An extra six weeks of medicines are reportedly being stockpiled in preparation for a no-deal Brexit.But Dominic Raab stopped short of giving a categoric assurance that patients would not be affected by a chaotic Brexit.                Jeremy Corbyn&rsquos MP SHOCK CLAIM: Labour will BLOCK more sanctions on...                Corbyn squirms when confronted AGAIN with simple Brexit questionThe Government's documents also revealed Britons visiting the EU could face extra credit card charges.Following the papers&rsquo release, Labour&rsquos shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer said Mr Raab's speech was &ldquothin on detail, thin on substance and provided no answers to how ministers intend to mitigate the serious consequences of leaving the EU without an agreement.He said: &ldquoA no-deal Brexit has never been viable and would represent a complete failure of the government's negotiating strategy.A further revelation contained within the Government&rsquos &lsquono-deal papers&rsquo was the health warning images currently used on cigarette packaging in the UK would have to be changed due to the copyright being held by the European Commission.The papers also stress: &ldquoIn a no deal there will be a UK system for regulations of paediatric medicines in which the UK will ensure incentives remain to encourage such medicines onto the UK market.The Government papers detail that checks could be cut back at UK borders.They say: &ldquoHMRC will work closely with industry to ensure its interventions are conducted in a way which minimises delays and additional burdens for legitimate trade, while robustly ensuring compliance.

title: gcse results day 2018 harder exams pass rate increase
story: Head Val Masson of The Albany School in Hornchurch, Essex, is thrilled with her pupils&rsquo achievements (Image: SWNS)One in five pupils gained at least one A, or a 7 under the new system, in England which now grades 20 subjects from the top grade of 9 to 1 &ndash other subjects retain the old system until they are phased in over the next two years.This year saw more than two-thirds pass and while girls still outperformed boys, the gap narrowed.The Joint Council for Qualifications said 17.2 per cent of boys scored a 7, up from 16.4 per cent last year.The percentage of girls with top grades remained the same at 23.7. The 6.5 per cent difference is the smallest gap since 2010 and the first time it has narrowed since 2007.Professor Alan Smithers of the University of Buckingham, said: &ldquoThe percentages getting 7 and above and 4 and above are up a bit this year.                GCSE results day 2018: What are GCSE grade boundaries?                 Ferrari in STITCHES as school minister fails to explain GCSE gradingSo Ofqual may have over-compensated for the fact that the people taking these exams are the first to do so and could have been disadvantaged. It looks as though the awarding of grades has been a lot more lenient.Overall the attainment gap between girls and boys getting at least a C or 4 has narrowed by 9.1 percentage points to last year&rsquos 9.5.Many GCSEs contained harder content and the Government hopes to match renowned education standards of countries like Singapore and Finland.Schools minister Nick Gibb said the new scoring system reflected &ldquomore demanding GCSEs.He added: &ldquoEmployers were complaining that old GCSEs were not educating people for the world of work and there was too big a gap between GCSEs and A-levels.The Crown&rsquos Finn Elliot gained 10 GCSEs (Image: PA)But Association of School and College Leaders general secretary Geoff Barton said: &ldquoWe are not clear why the Government felt it necessary to ratchet up the pressure to such an extent and what this was intended to achieve.Sally Collier, head of watchdog Ofqual, said: &ldquoStudents picking up their results can be confident they have achieved the grades their performances deserve.Identical 16-year-old triplets Jacques, Giselle and Benedict Barker, of Solihull, bagged 31 of the top A and A*, 9, 8 and 7 grades between them and classmates Ollie Mutch, of Rowledge, Hants, and Annie Chamberlain, from Alresford, may be the UK&rsquos smartest school friends after scoring all 9s in their GCSEs.Finn Elliot, 16, of Chichester, who played a young Prince Philip in The Crown, gained two A*s, one A, three 9s, three 8s, and a 7.He said: &ldquoThis is much scarier than being on TV.David and Francis Carian, aged seven and nine, from east London, are the youngest siblings to pass a GCSE, both achieving a 5 in maths.They were tutored by Professor Chris Imafidon, whose son Peter passed the exam at just six in 2006 through his father&rsquos Excellence in Education programme.

title: british people uptight stressed sore neck
story: British people queue quietly but not patiently  (Image: )Our devotion to queueing and unwillingness to complain or display our emotions all combine to cause tension headaches, sore shoulders and stiff necks.The quirky study on the &ldquostress of being British was commissioned by Warner Leisure Hotels, which questioned 2,000 adults over 50.Half (48 per cent) named queueing for anything and everything as the most typical British trait, closely followed by saying sorry unnecessarily (40 per cent) and being appalled at other people&rsquos bad manners (35 per cent).The vast majority (88 per cent) claimed they shared most of these characteristics &ndash particularly women.Yet 44 per cent felt stressed because of them at least once a week.                UK heatwave: Scorcher sees biggest ever harvest of TEA                Pub&rsquos landlord in froth as beer loses English pride Road rage and rudeness are two of our biggest peeves  (Image:  STOCK)And one in 10 believed their blood pressure went up as a result &ndash particularly men.Bad manners was the biggest irritation for women (42 per cent) followed by queue jumping (24.5 per cent).Men also hated bad manners (31 per cent) but got almost as frustrated about the behaviour of other motorists on the roads (28 per cent).The physical impact of the stress was almost twice as bad for women, though, bringing on headaches for 44 per cent, tense shoulders (39 per cent) or a sore neck (20 per cent).Walking proved the most popular way of dealing with the strain of it all, followed by listening to music, reading and relaxing in the bath.The Welsh are prone to take a hike when stressed out (Image: )People in Wales were most likely to go off hiking, while those from Glasgow tend to jump in the bath.While 25 per cent of those from the North-east say they do not do anything to relieve the tension, 45 per cent of Britons agree that we require more stress relief than other nations.Comedian Jenny Eclair, a self-confessed &ldquogrumpy old woman, said: &ldquoIt&rsquos a tough old gig being British. All that bottled-up stress that comes from our inability to say what we&rsquore really thinking can be a pain in the neck &ndash quite literally.&ldquoWe&rsquore so uptight in comparison to our friends overseas.

title: british uk self employed no pension
story: While self-employed workers are savers, the research found they are more focused emergencies (Image: )The figure of 43 per cent of self-employed people without a pension compares with just four per cent of those in regular employment.A record 4.8 million Britons work for themselves and account for 15 per cent of the workforce, but they are heading for a less comfortable retirement with many not planning to stop work.Nearly one in three says they will rely solely on the state pension &ndash currently worth &pound8,545 a year &ndash to fund their retirement, while 28 per cent say they will expect their business to provide the income they need.While self-employed workers are savers, the research found they are more focused on day-to-day emergencies than long-term retirement plans.                What state pension will you be entitled to?                State pension: How long can you defer and will you get more?Two-thirds (64 per cent) save to build up a safety net in case of an emergency in comparison with 57 per cent of those in regular employment.Just one in 10 of the self-employed sees a financial adviser regularly, despite having potentially more complex requirements.One in five (19 per cent) is not confident with money and financial matters, while fewer than a quarter (24 per cent) worry that they do not know enough about money.Kirsty Anderson, of pension firm Prudential which commissioned the study of 1,200 Britons, said: &ldquoSaving for retirement is tougher when you are self-employed as there is no one to organise a pension for you and no employer making contributions.&ldquoOn top of that self-employed workers often don&rsquot have a regular income so many will focus on setting aside money as a safety net.She added: &ldquoSaving for a pension is still important as no one wants to work for ever &ndash and no matter what your employment status, having money to fund your retirement is essential as the state pension is unlikely to be enough to fund a comfortable retirement.The Government-funded Money Advice Service advises self-employed people to set up one of three types of pension: ordinary, stakeholder with charges capped at 1.5 per cent, or selfinvested with a wider range of options but usually higher charges.Alternatively, the self-employed can use National Employment Savings Trust, which is the workplace scheme created for automatic enrolment.

title: sir chris hoy gold medal olympics trick lucky four leaf clover
story: Sir Chris winning gold at the 2012 London Olympic Games (Image: )Sir Chris, 42, shared a snap of his old bike saddle, showing what remains of the rare plant that was with him through years of success.The old clover, believed by many to bring good luck, can be seen in a plastic coin bag.The father-of-two from Edinburgh discovered his good luck charm while sorting through his old biking gear.Sharing two images on Twitter, he wrote: &ldquoGoing through some old bike kit today and found this a seat from my race bike with a 4-leaf clover stuck on the underside.                Laugh at my Lycra shorts if you dare, says HARRY HODGES                Lewis Hamilton: F1 champion to snub SPOTY awardsSir Chris in action  (Image: )&ldquoSo now you know the secret! In the past, Sir Chris has put his secret down to coffee.The athlete grew up in Murrayfield and began cycling at the age of six after reportedly being inspired by the 1982 film ET.He is an eleven-time world champion and six-time Olympic champion, making him the second most celebrated Olympic cyclist of all time, taking his first gold in Athens in 2004.Sir Chris won three gold medals at the 2008 Olympics in Beijing. He won his last two golds at the 2012 London Olympics.

title: glasgow orange parade diverted st alphonsus catholic church
story: The parade has been postponed and will be routed away from the church (Image: GOOGLE MAPS)Last month, it was the scene of an alleged assault on Canon Tom White while he was speaking to parishioners outside the church.A march scheduled at the end of July in the area was called off and the latest parade will be routed away from the church and start at 10.30am rather than noon.The Archdiocese of Glasgow welcomed the news. They tweeted: &ldquo@GlasgowCC has ordered a re-routing of Orange walk planned to pass St Alphonsus on Saturday.&nbsp&ldquoThe Archdiocese is grateful to the council for taking note of concerns and acting decisively to lift a cloud of anxiety affecting parishioners and residents.                Bigots face crackdown on Orange march day                Police warning as thousands take part in Orange Walk in GlasgowMarchers in last year's Orange Walk in Glasgow (Image: )Archdiocese of GlasgowA Glasgow City Council spokesman said: &ldquoA Public Processions Committee imposed an alternative route and start time on a proposed march by the Orange and Purple District 37 of County Grand Orange Lodge of Glasgow.&ldquoCommittee heard evidence from Police Scotland that significant disorder was likely, should the march take place on the original route.&ldquoThe march will begin at 10.30am, rather than 12 noon. It will not pass St Alphonsus&rsquo Church.A spokesman for the Grand Orange Lodge of Scotland said: &ldquoWe are extremely concerned at the decision to re-route a parade and effectively ban us from certain streets.&ldquoIt is discrimination in its purest form. Glasgow City Council has now established the first &lsquono-go zones&rsquo in Glasgow based purely on your religion.&ldquoWe offered numerous concessions, including moving the parade to a different day, continued discussion and dialogue and we identified the times of services at St Alphonsus&rsquo Church and offered to move the time of the parade to ensure we avoided those services.All of this was rejected. Instead we now have entire streets in Glasgow closed off at the request of one religion over another.&nbspA man has appeared at Glasgow Sheriff Court charged with assault following the incident last month. Bradley Wallace, 24, did not make any plea and the case was continued for further examination.

title: British fish and chip shop North Yorkshire chinese tourists hundreds
story: Chinese chippy! Tourists descend on British fish and chip shop  (Image: Tom MaddickScott's Chip Shop SWNS)Scott&rsquos Fish and Chips is situated near York and has been visited by coach loads of tourists eager to try the British classic.The takeaway said the Chinese tourists love the British classic at their shop because Chinese President Xi Jinping dined there with David Cameron.The meal occurred in 2015 when the then Prime Minister took the Chinese premier out for lunch.It is estimated over 100 tourists are enjoying a meal in the shop each week. story: Hurricane Lane NOAA cat 3 update: Lane has been downgraded to a category 3 storm (Image: NOAA)Hurricane Lane has been on a collision course with Hawaii&rsquos Big Island for several days as local residents batten down the hatches to prepare for deluges of rain, mass-scale flooding and damaging surf on Oahu - the most populated island.Pablo Akira Beimler, who lives on the coast in Honokaa on the Big Island, said: &ldquoRain has been nonstop for the last half hour or so, and winds are just starting to pick up.&ldquoOur usually quiet stream is raging right now.The hurricane&rsquos centre, or eye, packing maximum sustained winds of 130mph, was expected to move close to or over portions of the main islands later on Thursday or Friday, bringing dangerous surf of 20 feet (six metres) and a storm surge of up to four feet (one metre), storm forecasters said. title: children accused of witchcraft uk
story: But he was hiding a secret.Hed been sent to live with his aunt and uncle from the Democratic Republic of Congo after his mother passed away - but at this new home in Islington his relatives were accusing him of being a witch and seriously abusing him.Mardoche, now 26, was subjected to two years of exorcisms where pastors tried to coax the demons out of him through repetitive prayer, he tells Sun Online.He was starved to the point where he would search for dropped coins on the street to secretly buy food, sleep-deprived and threatened by his aunt and uncle.They even pulled a knife on him and said theyd kill him if he didnt stop being a witch.His relatives burned his precious possessions, including football medals and certificates, saying that he was using these to be able to gain enough power to fly.But Mardoche is not alone in suffering this type of abuse in the UK.Thousands of children are being put through these horrifying exorcisms - and they are taking place behind closed doors in flats, houses and churches on Britains streets.Whats more, theyre on the rise. Earlier this year, the Department of Education released figures showing there were over 1,400 child abuse cases across the UK that were linked to witchcraft and demonic possession beliefs between 2016 and 2017 - a 900% rise since 2011.And experts fear many more are flying under the radar as police and social services are too scared to intervene.Beliefs in witchcraft are still strongly-held within some communities in Central and Western African countries including Malawi, Nigeria, South Africa and Mardoches homeland, the DRC - and they have extended overseas to the UK.Football stars Isaac Success and Emmanuel Adebayor have blamed injuries and goal droughts on curses.And the tragic case of Victoria Climbié - the eight-year-old Ivorian girl who was murdered by relatives in Tottenham who believed she was possessed by demons - still haunts the country 18 years on.The most recent figures are just the tip of the iceberg according to experts such as Dr. Richard Hoskins, who has been researching African ritual crime for 15 years.As part of his research, Dr Hoskins has travelled to several African countries and witnessed disturbing exorcisms over there and in the UK.In the least invasive ones, children are typically made to abstain from eating and drinking water too, he says.The witchcraft - or kindoki as it is known there - will be shouted out to come out of the child in the name of Jesus, and the pastor might shake them too.These types of exorcisms is similar to what Mardoche experienced in churches and at home.I was pulled out of school and made to fast and kept up for days without sleep, he tells Sun Online.I was accused of flying in the night, killing my mother, putting curses on my family and even eating babies for dinner.I was so frightened Id be too scared to leave my bedroom to go to the toilet. Id wee in a bowl and pour it on the carpet but this made things worse as children who wet themselves are often accused of being possessed.Mardoche says he became withdrawn and felt he had no-one as his father was in the DRC.My relatives were clever. Although I was threatened, I wasnt beaten up. They were careful not to get caught.They took me to several pastors and advised me that the situation with my possession was so serious I would need to be sent back to the DRC.Thankfully, his school contacted social services. He ended up spending three months in a psychiatric unit as he became suicidal, before being placed in foster care.He is one of the lucky ones - if hed returned to the DRC it is likely he would have died due to the brutal exorcisms performed there.There, children are sliced by razor blades and knives in order to cut out the witchcraft, and have chilli pepper rubbed in their eyes.Dr Hoskins says: I also saw a little girl who was emaciated due to being starved for days - shed also not been given any water despite the boiling heat. She was almost at deaths door.Sometimes, children are pushed to the brink of death during exorcisms.Occasionally the perpetrators cross the line and end up killing the children in the process.This is what happened to 15-year-old Kristy Bamu, who was found dead in a bathtub in a council flat in East London on Christmas Day 2010.He had been staying with his sister Magalie Bamu and her boyfriend Eric Bakubi, when he was accused of bringing kindoki into their home.Kristy sustained 130 separate injuries after being attacked with an armoury of weapons - including metal bars and ceramic floor tiles smashed over his head - over a three-day period of exorcisms.He died due to drowning after being submerged in the bath towards the end of the ceremony.While in 2001, the torso of a young African boy, known only as Adam was found floating in the River Thames. He is believed to have been the victim of a brutal exorcism ritual.And Dr Hoskins says there could be many more cases of children that have been murdered that have gone unreported.Nobody is really sure how many cases there really are - of this kind of abuse and also children dying from it - because nobody wants to tackle it, he says.If you talk to anyone from these communities, they will say that pastors are pushing witchcraft beliefs on families.But because it is a belief system theres a perpetual fear [from the authorities] of stepping on peoples toes and causing offence.Half of UK police forces dont even record incidents and many local authorities are also unable to provide figures.We havent got past this political correctness when dealing with these case, adds Dr Hoskins.Because it is related to a belief system you hear from the Met police officers or even social services that they arent here to tackle beliefs, so nothing is done to stop it.But there needs to be a change because these belief systems tip over into abuse.Dr Hoskins says the witchcraft belief has roots in fundamentalist Christianity - where the words of the Bible are taken literally - and with traditional West and Central African superstitions beliefs.Theres a passage in the Bible that says sometimes a demon will be cast out and find seven more powerful ones, so even children that undergo exorcisms can be dragged through the whole system again a few months down the line, he says.But why is it children that are targeted?It is scapegoating, plain and simple, explains Dr Hoskins. Years ago, it was older women - the old crones who were branded witches.Many of these African countries have seen major problems in the last few years, such as civil war, economic deprivation and corruption - and when things go wrong in peoples lives they will blame a weaker party.Theres overpopulation too - Ive had people in these countries say to me that they cant afford to keep their children so they will force the idea of witchcraft on them in order to drive them out on the streets.Many children dont recover from the trauma of their abuse. Ive had them tell me their lives have been destroyed, says Dr Hoskins.Mardoche is one of the lucky ones: taken out of his abusive home, he built up his confidence through continuing to play football and now is a motivational speaker.He also works with various organisations to help teach people to spot the signs of children being accused of kindoki, and a film about his life, called Branded, will be released this autumn.However, he still lives with the effects of his experience.I find it difficult to get close to, and trust, other people, he admits. And at the time, I wanted to die. When youre constantly told youre evil, that youre to blame for your mothers death you start to believe it. Its not something that is easy to get over.My heart sinks every time I hear of another child being accused of being a witch, adds Dr Hoskins.The Government needs to take action to protect these young people and outlaw this belief system - we need criminal sentences for these pastors as what they are doing is abuse.We take a hard stance on terrorism in the name of religion, so there is no reason for us not to outlaw this. It leaves children mentally, emotionally and physically scarred for life.If you are affected by any of the issues raised in this article, please call the NSPCC on 0808 800 5000.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hotel staff confessions
story: The most salacious stories tend to emerge from hotel bedrooms, where sleeping is often the last thing guests have on their minds - and staff often have no choice but to turn a blind eye to kinky sex games, even the grooms who cheat on their wedding nights.At other times, theyre drafted in to deal with violent guests, dead bodies... and worse.Here, four hotel workers reveal all:Maria Smith, 26, is a mum of one. She lives on the Isle of Man and works as a pub manager.She says: I used to work in one of the island’s poshest hotels. We’d get British celebs like David Tennant staying all the time.They were easy to deal with and normally they checked in to chill out.But during the Isle of Man motorbike racing the high flyers would arrive.In the hotel we’d regularly see strippers strutting around offering private dances and other services to the guests.One well-to-do couple checked out looking prim and proper, but when my colleague opened the room to their bedroom it turned out theyd had a crazy sex party.They’d left behind huge dildos and filthy bedding.Dirty weekends are routine. There was one guy who had a suite on permanent reservation and had carousel of different women coming to stay with him.Guests regularly chat up the staff, and some would think nothing of manhandling us either.One famous older man pinched my bum when I was serving him. As soon as my hands were free I hit him with my tray.Deaths do happen though. One nasty incident involved an elderly guy who was staying for the TT motorbike race.His intestines had exploded and he haemorrhaged out in the room.The stench was awful - you could smell it along the corridor.The room was like a scene from a Quentin Tarrantino film with blood on the carpet, the bed and up the walls.You just have to clean it up as quickly as possible so the room is ready to rent again.Hotel receptionist Anna Thistlethwaite, 31 is a married mum of one who lives in Cambridge.She says: I have worked in the hotel industry for three years as front of house at a 4-star hotel in Hertfordshire.A common occurrence at weddings is for couples to go to their rooms - then when the bride passes out drunk the  groom goes and has sex with someone else.He’ll even go back and check his new wife is still asleep before returning to the woman in the other room. It happens a lot.We catch the blokes out because they always mix up the key cards.We make them wait at reception for as long as possible to reissue them with one for their room.One guest would check in every Friday night, pay for his room in cash and refuse to give any contact details.Forty-five minutes later a woman would literally run across the lobby and head towards his room.It was obvious he was cheating on his wife but we couldn’t work out if she was a prostitute or his mistress.We routinely see businessmen come in with different women during conference weeks.The wife normally joins them at the end none the wiser to what he has been up to.We have to keep a straight face and remember that the customer is always right.Josh Tully, 27, is general manager of La Vue France, boutique hotel &amp wedding venue in southwest France. He says:I used to work for an upscale UK establishment which was the destination for the rich and famous.One A-list Hollywood star flew in to give the bride away at her wedding.It was raining lightly and he refused to walk outside in case he ruined his Louis Vuitton suede loafers so we had to ensure there was a buggy available at all times to take him to and from the church and hotel.Anyone would have thought he was the bride.Another time, a guest who had reserved in advance asked us to ensure we had a £500 bottle of vintage Krug champagne on ice for his arrival.Our supplier let us down on the morning – so we improvised.We presented him with a bottle of the £20 house champagne and he was none the wiser.He thanked us for going to the trouble of getting it in and even explained how you could taste the difference.We kept a straight face and took the compliment.Other famous guests included a boy band who stayed to write songs.One of them had a fish only diet - each meal was fish guts, fish oil and fish blood whizzed up in a blender - It smelled disgusting.Yet we all had to go along with it and tell him how amazing he looked as a result of knocking back the revolting shots.One thing Ive learned is that people always seem to get frisky when they go away for the weekend.Once I walked into the games room only to find a couple having sex under the snooker table.They saw me but made the decision to carry on, so I left them to it.They just nodded at me when they eventually walked out.Maria Andrews, 29, lives in Northolt and is a married mum-of-one.She says:I worked in a 4-star hotel for the last five years. Nothing anyone does surprises me any more. I have delivered room service to a man who opened the door completely naked.I walked in and put the tray of two beers and some nibbles on the table. He wandered towards me. I didnt notice he was starker’s until I asked him to sign the bill.As I stood up his willy came into view. It was enormous - I can only assume he wanted to show it off.His wife was in bathtub next door also naked.Neither of them were drunk but - they were just blatant exhibitionists.Then there was the time a woman came downstairs in the middle of the night completely naked.She said shes got locked out after mistaking her room door for bathroom one.We didn’t believe a word of it. We suspect she got caught with someone she shouldn’t have been with and had to scarper.She had to stand at reception starkers while we ran her identity through the system.She had a great body which was just as well as the entire hotel staff saw the security footage of her streaking along the corridors.People behave badly from the moment they check in. I would never go back to the hotel industry. We were treated like sh*t.One man came the hotel to use the wifi. When we asked him to leave, he started threatening one of my colleagues with a glass bottle. I jumped on him and pinned him to the floor. It was just as well the police arrived because he was starting to choke.Guests also always assume if it isn’t nailed down then they can pinch it.After one wedding I clocked a woman trying to walk out with several 3-foot high centrepiece hidden under her coat.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may tory leadership contest trevor kavanagh opinion
story: While Theresa May tours the capitals of Europe looking for peace on Brexit, war has broken out between diehard Remainers and fervent Brexiteers.Ex-Ukip leader Nigel Farage has stormed back into the fray with Vote Leave II, a remake of his 2016 referendum triumph.In the pro-Brussels corner, Superdry fashion tycoon Julian Dunkerton is forking out £1million for what must surely be a futile, last-ditch bid to keep Britain in the EU.And just to make things extra interesting for the party conference season, the stampede for Mrs May’s Tory crown is already unstoppable.Indeed, the question is no longer if, or even when, the contest takes place. It is whether the PM herself will seize the initiative and signal her own plan to jump before she is pushed.The undeclared contest has transformed Britain’s negotiating stance — from Theresa May’s meek, slow-motion surrender to a strident demand for a decent, honourable settlement. The good news is that while MPs have been away on holiday, Brussels has begun to blink.At long last it has dawned on our EU neighbours that they have more to lose from a messy Brexit than we do.Forfeiting the UK’s £40billion ransom payment — plus our annual £12billion contribution — would instantly cripple the EU expansionary budget plans and plunge poorer nations such as Greece into crisis.Car and pharmaceutical giants, not to mention French farmers, who export vast stocks to the UK, would be plunged into crisis. Cooperation on crime, security and defence would be at risk. Governments across Europe are now piling pressure on Brussels to see sense.Tory leadership wannabes have sniffed the way the wind is blowing.The Tories won’t pick another Remainer as party leader. Nor does this Government have a prayer at the next election unless it can see off Nigel Farage and his Ukip insurgents with a deal that satisfies the 52 per cent who voted Leave.This explains a sudden enthusiasm at the top for stating the blindingly obvious: Britain will survive a clean Brexit, while an obstructive Brussels will be diminished.After two years of being bossed around by EU bully Michel Barnier, senior Cabinet ministers are coming out as born-again Eurosceptics. Foreign Secretary and repentant Remainer Jeremy Hunt admits Britain will experience some turbulence, but says the EU will be damaged “for a generation”.His warning is echoed by Brexit supremo Dominic Raab, who has rubbished “Project Fear” stories about food and medicine shortages.While loyally insisting a deal is “still the most likely outcome”, Mr Raab insists Britain will cope with the alternative.Hunt and Raab are now openly jockeying for the top job — along with Home Secretary Sajid Javid, Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson, Treasury chief Liz Truss and a host of others.Significantly, Michael Gove seems out of the race after endorsing Mrs May’s Chequers sellout. So where does this leave Boris Johnson? If tens of thousands of grass- roots Tory supporters have anything to do with it, he would be way out in front. As things stand, they don’t.BoJo is out of office and fighting confected outrage over Muslim face masks. Enemies such as the priestly Dominic Grieve threaten to quit the party if he is elected.Under present rules, Boris needs enough support from fellow MPs to be one of the two candidates submitted to party members for a final verdict. His rivals will do anything to stop him — which is why party activists are demanding rule changes to allow any MP with 20 votes to enter the final ballot.Boris has gone quiet — but not for long. He is reportedly planning a nationwide tour — complete with bright-red battle bus — trashing Mrs May’s Chequers deal and calling for a clean Brexit.There will be plenty of opportunities for car-crash interviews and zipwire-style TV images. But the bookies aren’t the only ones making BoJo the clear favourite as Britain’s next Prime Minister.He names Somalis, Ethiopians, North and Central Africans and Afghans as being responsible for the knife-gang slaughter of young black and Asian men.“Race is part of the picture,” says the equality campaigner. “Failing to point this out impedes the fight against these crimes and imperils yet more children of colour.”He is right, isn’t he?But how long before this decent black man is himself accused of racism for daring to tell this unvarnished truth?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa mays electoral prospects depend on how she deals with mass uncontrolled immigration post brexit
story: As usual, she’ll be more focused on the advice of civil servants than her own colleagues or the guidance from her Chief Whip or the wider Cabinet.She would be unwise to ignore the evidence from polls and her own MPs, that the settled opinion of the country is simply “thus far and no further” and that instead the best way to get back onto the front foot is to work up more concessions to the EU and specifically, surrendering the last major red line: On mass uncontrolled immigration via free movement.We can see clues of further surrender in the fuzzy language from the Chequers agreement: The Government is commitment to “allowing citizens to travel freely without a visa, for tourism and temporary business activity…” But what will “temporary” really mean? Will our current free movement regime be rebadged as a “Labour Mobility Framework”?Such a move, speculated on in the media this week, would be politically toxic and very poorly timed. It would also betray her own instincts, which she rightly gave voice to when she became Prime Minister.Striking a chord with millions of people angry and alienated at their voices being ignored by the political elite on immigration and the downside of globalisation, delivered for her record poll ratings then and a real feeling of hope that at last people in power were listening.Yes, the main driver for the Leave vote was about democracy, independence and national sovereignty but it was also about the fundamental choice that a UK outside the EU would have: Who comes to our country and on what basis – decided by our own Parliament.Voters have noticed that the tightening of the labour market and record employment levels, as revealed by the Office for National Statistics last week, mean that at long last real wages – i.e. pay packets less inflation – are slowly rising and that belatedly big business is beginning to move away from an over reliance on cheap foreign labour, undercutting the pay and conditions of indigenous workers and giving rise to higher welfare dependency.It might seem a radical concept, but such employers might just have to pay workers decent wages, train them better, improve their skills and try hard to retain them. That’s why EU workers are still coming to the UK in huge numbers, despite ridiculous Project Fear stories to the contrary.So yes – Brexit will mean higher pay for British workers! Top businessman Stuart Rose, briefly spokesman for the Remain campaign, accurately predicted such a development before the EU Referendum.Regrettably, the multinationals’ trades union, the CBI didn’t get the message: No surprise that they now want no restrictions on foreign workers post Brexit – in other words an endless pool of cheap labour just like now.Likewise, they’re happy to defend the growing gap between average pay and that of FTSE 100 bosses.Ironically, The Prime Minister could still snatch victory from defeat on this issue, notwithstanding her lamentable record as Home Secretary on reducing net immigration to the tens of thousands.The alternative White Paper which David Davis and his Ministers were working on prior to it being dumped at Chequers, was much more evidence-based and looked to many workable international examples of mobility agreements between first world countries like Australia, the United States, Japan and Canada, as a model for future EU-UK immigration arrangements, to our mutual benefit.The policy would have been informed by the Migration Advisory Committee which reports next month, focused on what was the sensible policy for the whole of the UK and all business sectors rather than a noisy minority and their well-paid advocates.It also sought to end the systemic bias towards low paid and low skilled EU citizens over the well qualified from across the globe.It was pro controlled immigration and not about pulling up the drawbridge and that’s where most British voters are now.Will Theresa May use the opportunity to keep faith with the millions of people in the north and the midlands, in south Wales and south west, who look to her to keep her promises and defend their interests and not just those of the well heeled, the multinationals and those comfortable with the Brussels status quo?Will putative leadership contender Sajid Javid have the courage to resist further attempts at craven supplication on continuing free movement in all but name? Will Conservative MPs who benefited from the highest ever blue collar vote for their party in history, ignore their own electors’ concerns and just accept further concessions?The electoral prospects of her party depend on it.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eu congratulates themselves for saving greece
story: Look at Greece now as it finally emerges from eight years of monstrous bailouts it will be paying back for decades.Savage cuts and tax rises have slashed its GDP by a quarter. A third of its ten million population are in poverty. One in five cannot afford electricity or rent.Forty per cent of young people are jobless. Many in work earn half what they did ten years ago.Hundreds of thousands of Greece’s brightest have fled.The Eurozone works nicely for Germany . . . but that’s it. Thank God we never signed up to it.Brexit Anxiety Disorder is real, two top psychologists believe. It certainly explains the gibbering hallucinations of Andrew Adonis and his mates.Two grievous losses tipped this complacent Remoaner elite over the edge:The control over our national direction to which they always felt entitled. And our departure from the corrupt, bullying, protectionist EU club they bizarrely consider a beacon of liberal values.Their latest co-ordinated ruse — backed by rich celebrities, has-been politicians and former newspapers — is to pretend a second referendum would “bring a divided Britain together”.They are actually arguing that after two years of abusing 17.4million Leavers as thick racists, Remainers now deserve a second chance to get what they wanted. And that, whatever the result, we would all magically unite behind it.If there’s a more laughably mad contention, we haven’t heard it.We might once have wondered what they were smoking. But the truth is simpler: they are just genuinely barking.It has known for a year the prison was dangerously understaffed. What were the MoJ officials onsite up to?The stories now emerging are appalling. Constant violence. Lags living in terror, warders more so. A “secure” staff car park torched. Routine use of drugs and synthetic highs, brazenly dropped by drones flown in by crime gangs.It’s not about whether prisons are run by the private or public sector. Too many of both are in a parlous state. Cuts have bitten too deeply — and the Government has just hoped for the best.It cannot go on. These jails shame modern Britain.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: stop being a jerk over jamie olivers recipes dawn butler sharing cultures enriches our world
story: Not because she had a bad spag bol in one of his restaurants.Not because he is crusading for a sugar tax that would hike up the price of some delicious drinks and treats.Not even because he once branded parents who occasionally give their kids junk food “tossers”.No, she is mad at him because he has committed the crime of “cultural appropriation”.In a bizarre Twitter rant, Butler, the MP for Brent Central, raged against Oliver’s latest supermarket product Punchy Jerk Rice.In her view, it is an act of cultural theft for a white British chef to make a ­Jamaican dish — or a botched version of a Jamaican dish, as she sees it.“I’m just wondering do you know what Jamaican jerk actually is?”, she asked the celeb chef. “Your jerk rice is not OK.”How weird for an MP to issue papal-style decrees on what chefs may and may not cook up in the kitchen.And then came her killer point: “This appropriation from Jamaica needs to stop.”There it is, the A-word. Appropriation.In the eyes of today’s politically correct policers of “wrongthink”, there is no greater crime than cultural appropriation.Cultural appropriation is when people embrace the grub or music or ideas of a culture that isn’t theirs.Like when Kylie Jenner wore her hair in cornrows. Or when Katy Perry donned a Japanese kimono. Or when drunken lads on a university campus put on sombreros as they neck shots of tequila.All of these things have been branded cultural appropriation by today’s potty warriors against “offensiveness”.And to this blacklist of things we must never appropriate, we can now add non-native foods.This is not the first time Jamie Oliver has been criticised for making foreign dishes. Two years ago foodies were up in arms when he put chorizo in paella — which the Spanish tend not to do.Clearly Jamie Oliver is only allowed to cook “white” British food, like roast beef and toad-in-the-hole.Not Cornish pasties or Yorkshire puddings, though.After all, what right does a man born in Essex have to appropriate the food of Northerners and people from the West Country? And presumably Dawn Butler only ever tucks into Jamaican dishes.If it is cultural appropriation for Oliver to make jerk grub, surely it must be cultural appropriation for Ms Butler to rattle up a bit of sushi?This would be the crazy conclusion to the war on cultural appropriation — none of us would ever dip into other cultures and experience their pleasures.What is most depressing about the Butler/Oliver spat is that it confirms how mainstream the miserabilist, divisive PC worldview has gone.It used to be just time-rich posh kids and snowflakes on university campuses who raged against cultural appropriation.Like the officious students at Cambridge who banned an Around The World in 80 Days fancy-dress party for fear students would wear “culturally appropriated” costumes.Or the clipboard bores at the University of East Anglia who banned students from wearing sombreros.Or the easily offended muppets at the University of Ottawa in Canada who banned a yoga class, because for white people to indulge in this ancient Indian discipline is an act of “cultural genocide”.I bet you never knew that when you do a pelvic tilt at your local gym you are being a horrible racist.Now, however, with Butler’s missive against the crimes of Jamie Oliver, this PC claptrap has crept from the fringes into the political centre. Butler is Shadow Secretary for Women and Equalities, and she is very close to Jeremy Corbyn.Is this what we should expect under a Corbyn government? Finger-wagging at anyone who deviates from PC rules?The worst thing about the clampdown on cultural appropriation is how divisive it is. The message is that we must always stick with our own cultures and never borrow from others.Didn’t that used to be known as racism?In recent years, Beyonce has been slammed for wearing a sari. Glastonbury has banned attendees from wearing Native American head-dresses. Selena Gomez was ridiculed for doing a Bollywood- inspired dance on US TV.This new racial divisiveness makes ­culture stiff and dull.Anthony Horowitz, author of the Alex Rider teen spy novels, says he was “warned off” from writing a black character. Apparently a white writer like him ­cannot understand the black experience.Is this really the world we want to live in? Where people never mix and never try to empathise with those who have had different life experiences to theirs?We should stand up for cultural ­appropriation.The global intermingling of food and fashion and art has enriched human life.As the great American novelist Lionel Shriver reminds us: “People with different backgrounds rubbing up against each other and exchanging ideas and practices is self-evidently one of the most productive, fascinating aspects of modern urban life.”Yet in their Brave New World, everyone would stick to their own people and their own ways. What a dispiriting, divided world that would be.I would far rather live in a world than has Jamie Oliver jerk chicken in it than in such a racially regimented PC nightmare.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: expat pension no deal brexit
story: Most at risk are Brits who have worked in EU countries and built up pension funds abroad that are then paid into a UK bank account.Under Brussels pensions rules, funds that cross borders can only be paid into a bank account registered in an EU country.Pensioners who have worked in the EU and now live in countries outside the union are currently made to open bank accounts in an EU state to collect their funds.The UK will become a “third country” on 30 March 2019, sparking the risk of expats and former expats with British bank accounts having their payments cut off.The shocking admission comes in the first tranche of No Deal contingency plans are published by Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab later on Thursday.Leaked details seen by The Sun show Ministers are braced for lost access to pensions for UK expats in the EU.In the Financial Services Technical Note, the Treasury will also admit that the City risks turmoil on “Day One” due to the loss of “passporting” rights that allows financiers to work across borders.And The Sun can also reveal:Mr Raab will unveil 25 technical notes on Thursday, alongside a speech where he will claim a duty, as a responsible government, to plan for every eventuality.He will argue the contingency plans are “a sensible, measured,and proportionate approach to minimising the impact of no deal on British firms, citizens, charities and public bodies.”And he will pledge the Government will do everything it can to “facilitate the smooth, continued, functioning of business, transport, infrastructure, research, aid programmes and funding streams.”In some cases, it means taking unilateral action to maintain as much continuity as possible in the short term, in the event of no deal — irrespective of whether the EU reciprocates.THE NHS will avoid running out of critical supplies in a No Deal Brexit by automatically recognising European standards on drugs and medical equipment, contingency plans show.A technical note on Batch Testing of Medicine due to be published later today says Brussels testing rules will be respected so that “imported medicines will not need to be retested.” The move is designed to see off a back log of medical supplies shipped into Britain at the border.On Monday Exit Secretary Dominic Raab blasted “scare stories” about the NHS running out of drugs if Brexit talks collapse, with Ministers vowing to keep supply chains running.EU rules on organs, tissue and blood will also be automatically taken in to British law in the No Deal scenario.And Brussels standards on drugs and medical equipment will automatically be taken onto UK statue books on “Day One” to prevent any threat to the NHS.Health boss Matthew Hancock has reassured more than 100 NHS importers that a crack team of specialist will be set up by next March to monitor supply chains and stocks.And this summer a “comprehensive assessment” of all supply chains has been secretly undertaken.Last night Victoria Hewson of the Institute of Economic Affairs said: As long as the Government makes arrangements to ensure a no-deal scenario is workable for businesses and consumers alike, we wont run out of food, planes will still fly and the sick will still receive their medicines.She added: These steps will ensure access to safe medical products and devices. Supplies won’t dry up and prices for drugs won’t rise.Mr Raab will also make a plea to Brussels to mimic Britain by being “responsible European neighbours, partners and allies,” suggesting it would even be sensible to work together “when it comes to No Deal planning.”But on Wednesday Labour’s Owen Smith MP hit back: It beggars belief that more than two years after the Brexit vote, the Government are making speeches and publishing ‘notes’ on what happens if they can’t secure a deal.”The Best for Britain backer, warned: “no amount of contingency planning or spin can hide the fact that the peace and prosperity of our country is at risk.”Last night, Tory Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg urged the party to “respect the referendum”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
